thread.title: Senate Takes First Procedural Step To Dismantle Obamacare
thread.title_full: Senate Takes First Procedural Step To Dismantle Obamacare

author: Jack Davis
title: Senate Takes First Procedural Step To Dismantle Obamacare
text:
Senate Takes First Procedural Step To Dismantle Obamacare "Today, we take the first steps ..." by Jack Davis January 3, 2017 at 2:52pm Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
The Senate on Tuesday took its first action toward repealing Obamacare as Sen. Mike Enzi, R-Wyo., introduced a resolution that will allow a repeal to move forward this month. 
GOP Senators are using a budget resolution to accomplish their goal of repealing parts of Obamacare. Various committees are required to report back by Jan. 27 how their approach to dismantling Obamacare will impact taxes and spending, with Senate action expected at that time. 
That tactic means that instead of the 60 votes necessary to pass legislation, only a simple majority will be required. Republicans hold 52 seats in the 100-seat Senate. Advertisement - story continues below Related Stories Priebus: ‘Repeal and Replace’ At The Top Of Trump’s Agenda 
As efforts to repeal got under way on Capitol Hill, President-elect Donald Trump fired off two tweets about the need for repealing the healthcare law. People must remember that ObamaCare just doesn't work, and it is not affordable – 116% increases (Arizona). Bill Clinton called it "CRAZY" 
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) January 3, 2017 The Democrat Governor.of Minnesota said "The Affordable Care Act (ObamaCare) is no longer affordable!"– And, it is lousy healthcare. 
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) January 3, 2017 Advertisement - story continues below 
Repealing Obamacare was among the top Republican priorities during the 2016 campaign. 
“Americans face skyrocketing premiums and soaring deductibles,” Enzi said in a statement. 
“Insurers are withdrawing from markets across the country, leaving many families with fewer choices and less access to care than they had before — the opposite of what the law promised,” he said. 
“Today, we take the first steps to repair the nation’s broken health-care system, removing Washington from the equation and putting control back where it belongs: with patients, their families and doctors,” he added. Advertisement - story continues below
